Notes: The Investment Advisers Act (SEC Rule 206(4)-7) outlines three straightforward requirements for who can be designated as a CCO. They must have: Competence and knowledge regarding Advisers Act requirements · Authority to develop and enforce appropriate policies · Sufficient seniority to ensure compliance across the firm · Notably absent from these requirements are stipulations on specific licensing, continuing education mandates, or prescribed industry experience. This level of flexibility paved the way for an explosion of outsourced CCO solutions, not all of which are created equal.
